Award.AwardTitle: Cincinnati Symposium on Probability Theory and Applications 2014, September 19-21, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cincinnati Symposium on Probability Theory and Applications 2014 will take place September 19 to 21, 2014 at the University of Cincinnati with a focus on current research in limit theorems for dependent structures. Dependent structures are ubiquitous in physical applications, yet present many mathematical challenges. Several important breakthroughs have been made in recent years by combining ideas from two or more of the Symposium focus areas. The Symposium will provide a platform to showcase recent developments and stimulate new cross-disciplinary investigations and collaborations. In order to stimulate new ideas and assist with the professional development of young probabilists, the Symposium will emphasize the participation of graduate students and recent PhD recipients. Besides invited talks by senior researchers, there will be ample opportunities for young investigators to present their research in shorter talks and at a poster forum. By providing travel support, especially to junior probabilists, this award will facilitate interactions and potential collaborations between junior and more established researchers, and encourage the infusion of new ideas across probability and related fields.

Recently, significant progress has been made in understanding how classical limit theorems persist or break down when the assumption of weak dependence is not valid. At the same time, models with complex dependence structures, notably arising from random matrix theory and mathematical physics, present new challenges to probabilists. The Symposium will bring together experts and junior researchers working on
1) almost sure limit theorems via martingale approximations,
2) long-range dependence phenomena and infinite ergodic theory, and
3) spectra of large-dimensional random matrices.


Symposium website: http://math.uc.edu/probability

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cincinnati Symposium on Probability Theory and Applications 2014 was held September 19 to 21, 2014 at the University of Cincinnati.  The major goal of the symposium was to share recent developments and stimulate new cross-disciplinary investigations and collaborations concerning limit theorems for dependent structures.  Recently, significant progress has been made in understanding how classical limit theorems persist or break down when the assumption of weak dependence is not valid. At the same time, models with complex dependence structures, notably arising from random matrix theory and mathematical physics, present new challenges to probabilists. Several important breakthroughs have been made in recent years by combining ideas from different fields. The symposium brought together experts and junior researchers in dependent structures from across mathematics and statistics.  This created a platform to showcase recent developments and stimulate new cross-disciplinary investigations and collaborations at a time that is ripe for new progress to be made through the innovative use of new techniques.

The symposium was very successful, with 15 invited speakers, 13 poster presenters, and 19 other participants.  Mathematicians from 27 institutions participated from 13 states as well as Canada, the Czech Republic, and France.  A major goal of the symposium was to bring together junior and senior probabilists in order for graduate students and postdocs to have a forum to learn about the latest results in the field, present their own results in the poster session, and develop professional connections.  The symposium was successful in attracting a diverse array of probabilists from all career stages, including 2 undergraduate students (who presented posters), 12 graduate students, and 7 postdocs.

Dependent structures are ubiquitous in physical applications, ranging from traffic flow models to finance to wireless communications. Understanding limit theorems for dependent structures is important for developing the mathematical theory for these phenomena. The Symposium featured talks and poster presentations focusing on a variety of these applications, including the use of random matrices in population genetics, the performance stability of clinical protein measurements, and efficient seed collection strategies for the genetic conservation of the American Chestnut.
